definition: to angle for fame (idiom)/to fish for compliments
abbr. for Tianjin 天津 (also 津沽)
to buy/to sell
name/noun (part of speech)/place (e.g. among winners)/famous/classifier for people
to fish with a hook and bait
to praise/to acclaim/reputation

sentences.english: Many people value fame and seek fame.
Some say the fish for fame, not long dry on the steering political springboard.
sentences.chinese: 也有人说是沽名钓誉，干不长时间就转向政治跳板。

sentences.english: Nothing is more detestable than the man who courts popularity.
sentences.chinese: 再没有比沽名钓誉的人更令人厌恶了。

sentences.english: He wants no members in his political party who are just along for the ride.
sentences.chinese: 他不要任何沽名钓誉，搭顺风车的人在他的政党里。

sentences.english: She is always fishing for compliments.
He never trusted fame, and always boxed up and guarded his ego.
sentences.chinese: 他从不沽名钓誉，而是保持距离，忠于自我。

sentences.english: Those who fish for fame and honors will end up nowhere.
sentences.chinese: 沽名钓誉的人最后将一事无成。

sentences.english: Generally to say, is enthusiastic pursuit of the world in general.
sentences.chinese: 总括地说，世人一般所热心的是沽名钓誉。
